ygData.subject: New Publication on Evolving the HyperNEAT Substrate
ygData.msgSnippet: After years of speculation on how the placement and density of nodes might be evolved in the HyperNEAT substrate, Sebastian Risi, Joel Lehman, and I are

Subject: New Publication on Evolving the HyperNEAT Substrate
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=uA69741uFPwQsPyj9EjwxlPEa1K6Pu3XuEF0-1ZWqCutfBRBnOQz
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

After years of speculation on how the placement and density of nodes might =
be evolved in the HyperNEAT substrate, Sebastian Risi, Joel Lehman, and I a=
re pleased to announce our contribution to this conversation.  Our paper, "=
Evolving the Placement and Density of Neurons in the HyperNEAT Substrate," =
which will be presented at GECCO this year, is available here:

http://eple=
x.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/risi.gecco10.html
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/pa=
pers/risi_gecco10.pdf

This paper introduces a theory on how node placement=
 should relate to connectivity and then applies that theory to construct an=
 algorithm that derives the placement and density of hidden neurons in the =
substrate automatically.  One interesting aspect of this new approach (call=
ed Evolvable Substrate HyperNEAT or ES-HyperNEAT) is that it introduces no =
new representation at all.  In other words, the CPPN is no different than i=
t was for traditional fixed substrate evolution.  Thus ES-HyperNEAT can be =
applied as HyperNEAT normally would be yet now without worrying about where=
 to place hidden nodes or how many there should be. We hope this paper will=
 provoke renewed thinking and ideas on the subject of substrate evolution, =
and we will be interested to hear your thoughts.  As far as we know, this p=
aper is the first to be published on this subject.

ken
